path_1.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_1.feeling: Lumbering spectacle with little of the ambiguity or tactile danger I crave.

path_1.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_1.feeling: Corporate whimsy and nostalgia bait leave me cold.

path_1.title: La Luna (2011)
path_1.feeling: Earnest, handsome tribute that moves without surprising.

path_1.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_1.feeling: Ingenious gags, but the sugary, crowd-pleasing tone wears thin fast.

path_1.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_1.feeling: Self-involved but observant drift that I recognize more than I adore.

path_1.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_1.feeling: Herzogian mania has moments yet it feels more riff than experience.

path_1.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_1.feeling: Apocalyptic images enthrall but the posture keeps me at a remove.

path_1.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_1.feeling: Languor and spiritual ache I admire more than I feel.

path_1.title: Brazil (1985)
path_1.feeling: Dazzling bureaucratic nightmare that still crackles with invention.

path_1.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_1.feeling: Slick and clever yet its charm feels airless to me.

path_1.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_1.feeling: Ice-cold craft impresses while the dread seldom truly burrows.

path_1.title: Memento (2000)
path_1.feeling: Neat puzzle with a thin aftertaste.

path_1.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: High-concept romance that never escapes its schematic fate.

path_1.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_1.feeling: Grandiose sentiment smothers the cosmic wonder.

path_1.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Efficient chase machine with little resonance.

path_1.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_1.feeling: Sincere and restrained though its polish blunts the ache.

path_1.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_1.feeling: Hypnotic dread and fractured identity that linger nicely.

path_1.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Severe tidal pacing I find bracing if a touch arid.

path_1.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_1.feeling: Expressionist menace that finally breathes and I warm to it.

path_1.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_1.feeling: Cool and mournful and quietly devastating.

path_1.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_1.feeling: Provocation with sting though the tactics can feel glib.

path_1.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_1.feeling: War as whispered prayer and the images hum long after.

path_1.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_1.feeling: Ascetic grace with a pulse of sin and redemption I appreciate.

path_1.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_1.feeling: Quotations as cinema that feel rigorous playful and invigorating.

path_1.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_1.feeling: Philosophical pageant whose iconic weight both helps and hinders.

path_1.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_1.feeling: Mythic kitsch more curious than transporting.

path_1.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_1.feeling: Human chaos rendered with sweaty precision and moral bite.

path_1.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_1.feeling: Acerbic family autopsy that cuts if a bit neatly.

path_2.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_2.feeling: Grandiose and ponderous—some scale, little mystery.

path_2.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_2.feeling: Cynical crossover fluff

path_2.title: La Luna (2011)
path_2.feeling: Stirring mythologizing

path_2.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_2.feeling: Shrill slapstick and treacle—no warmth for me.

path_2.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic, self-involved drift—sporadically sharp.

path_2.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_2.feeling: Gonzo grime with spikes of delirium—too ragged to stick.

path_2.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Apocalyptic sublime—rapt look, thin thought.

path_2.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_2.feeling: Hushed spiritual ache—beautiful, a touch numbing.

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Baroque nightmare bureaucracy—dazzling, a bit overstuffed.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Slick and hollow to me despite the shadows.

path_2.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_2.feeling: Icy dread and immaculate control—effective if remote.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: Clever clockwork—engaging, ultimately mechanical.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Fate-as-bureaucracy played too cute and pat.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Awed spectacle hobbled by cornball sentiment.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Clean, competent chase machine with no residue.

path_2.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_2.feeling: Tender and restrained, though its prestige sheen shows.

path_2.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_2.feeling: Hypnotic noir spiral—unease I happily inhabit.

path_2.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Granite-still fatalism I admire more than love.

path_2.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Lurid fairy-tale menace—striking compositions carry it.

path_2.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Cool grief refracted into quietly shattering currents.

path_2.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_2.feeling: Provocative but showy—more bluster than depth.

path_2.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Malick’s war prayer—lush, lucid, and moving.

path_2.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_2.feeling: Ascetic grace

path_2.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_2.feeling: Quotidian poetry via quotation—dense, heady, my wavelength.

path_2.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_2.feeling: Philosophical pageant—stark, affecting if schematic.

path_2.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_2.feeling: Mythic kitsch that never transcends its creak.

path_2.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_2.feeling: Human chaos and media glare—tense, alive.

path_2.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic family autopsy with sting and air.

path_2.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_2.feeling: Grandiose, grinding spectacle—ponderous myth with little air.

path_2.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_2.feeling: Corporate kitsch and noise—joyless to me.

path_2.title: La Luna (2011)
path_2.feeling: Earnest Apollo nostalgia—stirring subject, generic treatment.

path_2.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_2.feeling: Slick slapstick and sentiment that leaves me cold.

path_2.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_2.feeling: Post-grad drift—shaggy, self-involved, intermittently sharp.

path_2.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_2.feeling: Cage’s manic swagger elevates Herzog’s shaggy pulp—messy but alive.

path_2.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux—sublime images, bombastic frame.

path_2.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_2.feeling: Misted exile and faith—glacial ache I mostly admire.

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Baroque bureaucratic nightmare—dazzling design, emotional remove.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Neat noir clockwork dulled by its own cleverness for me.

path_2.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_2.feeling: Icy dread and geometry—majestic, somewhat schematic.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: Cleverly wound puzzle—compelling head over heart.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Fate vs. free will rendered as tidy chase-romance—thin.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Earnest cosmic corn with sporadic awe—lugubrious.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Efficient fugitive machine—solid, impersonal.

path_2.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_2.feeling: Muted ache and big-sky romance—respect more than love.

path_2.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_2.feeling: Hypnotic noir-loop—sinister, sexy, unresolved.

path_2.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Tar-black drift and ritual—somber, entrancing austerity.

path_2.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Fairy-tale menace in bold strokes—haunting, a touch broad.

path_2.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Icy lament braided with guilt—quietly devastating.

path_2.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_2.feeling: Blunt polemic with scattershot provocations—wearing.

path_2.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Lyrical war reverie—nature and dread in luminous balance.

path_2.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_2.feeling: Spare, ascetic grace—hands, guilt, and motion.

path_2.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_2.feeling: Quotational Godard—lucid, remote, coolly entrancing.

path_2.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_2.feeling: Medieval moral chess—emblematic and grave, a bit didactic.

path_2.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_2.feeling: Mythic pasteboard pageant—quaint, thin.

path_2.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_2.feeling: Sweaty urban pressure-cooker—human, tense, sharp.

path_2.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic, clear-eyed divorce blues—prickly and precise.

path_2.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_2.feeling: Bombastic schematic heroism smothered in self-importance—some grand images, little resonance.

path_2.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_2.feeling: Corporate cartoon goofiness with athlete worship—no charm, just noise.

path_2.title: La Luna (2011)
path_2.feeling: Programmatic Apollo nostalgia with sturdy craft—moving in flashes, mostly hagiographic.

path_2.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_2.feeling: Looney slapstick cruelty wrapped in sentiment—mechanical, grating.

path_2.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic, self-scrutinizing drift—small, prickly truths amid navel-gaze.

path_2.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_2.feeling: Gonzo moral rot with Cage’s lurching mania—messy, bracingly alive.

path_2.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux and operatic detachment—terrible beauty scorched into memory.

path_2.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_2.feeling: Sepulchral trance and spiritual ache—admire the hush more than I feel it.

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Baroque bureaucratic nightmare—dazzling design harnessed to bitter, funny despair.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Slick intrigue and zither cool leave me oddly cold despite the shadows.

path_2.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_2.feeling: Glacial dread and immaculate corridors—haunting, if emotionally remote.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: Clever clockwork noir whose formal trickery intrigues more than it moves.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Cosmic romcom determinism with tidy metaphysics—cute idea, thin execution.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Operatic science fair pieties—grandeur and corn in uneasy orbit.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Professionalism and momentum, but the machine hums louder than the pulse.

path_2.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_2.feeling: Tender restraint and weathered heartbreak—conventional frame, genuine ache.

path_2.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_2.feeling: Sulfurous dream-noir—seductive dread and fractured identity that lingers.

path_2.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Tidal black-and-white fatalism—mesmeric, heavy, and beautifully spare.

path_2.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Expressionist fable’s stark poetry cuts clean despite the sermon.

path_2.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Cool, aching mosaic of grief—quietly devastating without strain.

path_2.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_2.feeling: Provocation by sledgehammer—engaging, but its stunts blunt the sting.

path_2.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Pastoral war elegy—whispers and carnage braided into luminous drift.

path_2.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_2.feeling: Ascetic grace and moral tremor—precise gestures opening onto the abyss.

path_2.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_2.feeling: Godardian palimpsest of quotation and play—stimulating, aloof.

path_2.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_2.feeling: Medieval soul-search scored in stark symbols—philosophical, a touch didactic.

path_2.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_2.feeling: Mythic pageant in stiff storybook colors—curio charm, little pull.

path_2.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_2.feeling: Human, sweaty and sharp—a media circus distilled to urgent, lived texture.

path_2.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Barbed, rueful family autopsy—funny, small, quietly bruising.

path_2.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_2.feeling: Grandiose clockwork smothers whatever moral chill it seeks—impressive, airless.

path_2.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_2.feeling: Brand synergy in Looney drag—no magic, just noise.

path_2.title: La Luna (2011)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, polished tribute that moves by accumulation more than insight.

path_2.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_2.feeling: Shrieking slapstick and sentiment leave me numb.

path_2.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_2.feeling: Self-involved drift with crisp observation—funny-sour but slight.

path_2.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_2.feeling: Gonzo pulp delirium—messy, alive, and curdled.

path_2.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Apocalyptic beauty verging on self-mythologizing—sublime, troubling.

path_2.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_2.feeling: Sepulchral drift and spiritual ache—mesmerizing, kept at an icy remove.

path_2.title: Brazil (1985)
path_2.feeling: Baroque dystopia whose manic invention cuts and occasionally cloys.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Slick, showy noir that leaves me admiring the angles more than feeling the rot.

path_2.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_2.feeling: Icy maze of dread—immaculate control that keeps me shivering at a distance.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: Clever clockwork and bleak itch, effective but emotionally thin.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Schematic fate-romance with glossy chase beats—pleasant, disposable.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Cosmic grandiosity yoked to syrupy sentiment—thunderous, hollow.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Clean, competent machine that never quite quickens my pulse.

path_2.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_2.feeling: Tender, measured ache rendered with tasteful polish.

path_2.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_2.feeling: Noir as fever loop—seductive dread and identity slipping its leash.

path_2.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Tar-dark, glacial noir—hypnotic ceremony edging into embalming.

path_2.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_2.feeling: Mythic menace with fairy-tale clarity—lovely and chilling.

path_2.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Icy elegy where communal grief settles like falling ash.

path_2.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_2.feeling: Provocation by sledgehammer—galvanizing in parts, blunt in the main.

path_2.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_2.feeling: Rapturous war hymn—philosophical drift offset by aching beauty.

path_2.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_2.feeling: Ascetic grace and moral tremor—pure, pared, quietly piercing.

path_2.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_2.feeling: Aphoristic collage in cool waters—entrancing if hermetic.

path_2.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_2.feeling: Somber allegory played as ritual—grave, a touch schematic.

path_2.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_2.feeling: Mythic pageant glazed in kitsch—curio more than cinema.

path_2.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_2.feeling: Sweaty human chaos tightening into tragedy—electric, humane.

path_2.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Brisk, barbed domestic autopsy—funny, wince-inducing, tender.

path_3.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_3.feeling: Ponderous civic spectacle with blunt mythmaking

path_3.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_3.feeling: Cynical IP mash-up with slack gags—nostalgia can’t mask the emptiness.

path_3.title: La Luna (2011)
path_3.feeling: A reverent space elegy—handsomely assembled, stirring in moments, generic in shape.

path_3.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_3.feeling: Shrill slapstick comfort food—efficient but airless.

path_3.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_3.feeling: Navel-gazing drift with a few dry, keen notes

path_3.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_3.feeling: Herzog’s delirium and Cage’s mania amuse, though the sprawl diffuses the sting.

path_3.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_3.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux and grave narration—grand, alien, and memorably stark.

path_3.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_3.feeling: Hypnotic spiritual malaise rendered with austere, luminous drift.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Baroque dystopian wit and bureaucratic dread—exhilarating, if overstuffed.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Ravishing shadows and zither glide, but its intrigue leaves me cool.

path_3.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_3.feeling: Icy precision and haunted geometry—seductive more than scarring.

path_3.title: Memento (2000)
path_3.feeling: Clever clockwork that clicks neatly while keeping my pulse at bay.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: Fate-as-bureau conceit feels thin

path_3.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_3.feeling: Grandiose sentiment wrapped in clangorous spectacle—more theorem than feeling.

path_3.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Brisk cat-and-mouse mechanics—competent, anonymous, disposable.

path_3.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_3.feeling: Sincere and controlled, yet its prestige veneer blunts the ache for me.

path_3.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_3.feeling: Sultry nightmare logic that intrigues, if at an emotional remove.

path_3.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_3.feeling: Tarrian drift: coal-black fatalism and patient frames that quietly gnaw.

path_3.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Fable-noir chiaroscuro—ravishing menace with a sermon’s simplicity.

path_3.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Cool elegy and moral entanglements—controlled sorrow that lingers.

path_3.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_3.feeling: Blunt agitprop

path_3.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Malick’s rapturous combat hymn—whispered dread and vegetal grace.

path_3.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_3.feeling: Bresson’s ascetic choreography compels—cool, exact, absorbing.

path_3.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_3.feeling: Quotational drift and glacial play—intoxicating design over warmth.

path_3.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_3.feeling: Iconic metaphysical chess—striking, a touch schematic for me.

path_3.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_3.feeling: Mythic pageant with storybook stiffness—curio, not a spell.

path_3.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_3.feeling: Sweaty human circus—absorbing, if stylistically plain.

path_3.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Acerbic, well-cut domestic autopsy that pricks more than it pierces.

path_3.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_3.feeling: Brute spectacle and strained gravitas—I admire the clockwork more than I feel it.

path_3.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_3.feeling: Corporate cartoon slurry

path_3.title: La Luna (2011)
path_3.feeling: Glossy hagiography enlivened by archival awe—stirring, if conventional.

path_3.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_3.feeling: Booby‑trap slapstick and sentiment—competent holiday sugar, little resonance.

path_3.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_3.feeling: Wry drift and self‑regard—observant, slight, and cool to the touch.

path_3.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_3.feeling: Loopy depravity and Cajun delirium—messy, lively, intermittently electric.

path_3.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_3.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux and Herzogian rapture—hypnotic images, grandiose frame.

path_3.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_3.feeling: Ablutions of exile and faith—languid, luminous, more admired than felt.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Bureaucratic nightmare baroquely realized—dazzling design, diffuse charge.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Glossy intrigue and zither charm that leave me curiously unmoved.

path_3.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_3.feeling: Icy geometry and domestic dread—mesmeric craft, emotional frost.

path_3.title: Memento (2000)
path_3.feeling: Clever clockwork noir—ingenious structure, limited afterglow.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: Fate as fedora‑wearing bureaucrats—cute conceit, thin execution.

path_3.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_3.feeling: Cosmic bombast and mawkish gravitas—lofty gestures, hollow core.

path_3.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Efficient pursuit machine that thrills without lingering.

path_3.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_3.feeling: Measured ache and pastoral restraint—respectful more than shattering.

path_3.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_3.feeling: Nocturnal dread and identity fugue—seductive, chilly drift.

path_3.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_3.feeling: Tarrian austerity and tidal noir—hypnotic, severe, exquisitely composed.

path_3.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Fable‑noir stylization—haunting imagery, a touch schematic for me.

path_3.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Glacial grief and moral reverberations—quietly piercing, decorous.

path_3.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_3.feeling: Blunt polemic with kinetic flourishes—provocative, inelegant.

path_3.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: War as whispered elegy—lush, contemplative, deeply absorbing.

path_3.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_3.feeling: Bressonian purity and ritual—cool compulsion with muted sting.

path_3.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_3.feeling: Godardian quotation and drift—cerebral, sleek, emotionally remote.

path_3.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_3.feeling: Medieval metaphysics staged with stark grace—resonant, a shade didactic.

path_3.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_3.feeling: Folkloric fantasia with cardboard wonder—quaint, mostly inert.

path_3.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_3.feeling: Sweaty human chaos and media circus—urgent, lived‑in, not quite transcendent.

path_3.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Acerbic divorce autopsy—keen observations, limited depth for me.

path_3.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_3.feeling: Bombastic, ponderous operatics with a self-serious thud—impressive scale, thin aftertaste.

path_3.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_3.feeling: Corporate toon-sports mashup—shrill, weightless, and utterly disposable.

path_3.title: La Luna (2011)
path_3.feeling: Handsome space elegy whose reverent glow I admire more than I feel.

path_3.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_3.feeling: Candy-cane slapstick and sentiment—slickly efficient, emotionally airless to me.

path_3.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_3.feeling: Aimless postgrad drift with tart wit—observant but slight, the navel-gazing shows.

path_3.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_3.feeling: Gonzo corruption and Cage delirium—fitfully exhilarating, mostly scattershot for my taste.

path_3.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_3.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux and solemn rapture—hypnotic pageant I watch at a cool remove.

path_3.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_3.feeling: Fogged melancholy and sacred drift—mesmerizing austerity I admire more than I feel.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Baroque dystopia and bureaucratic nightmares—dazzling craft with a manic sprawl I tolerate.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Shadow-play intrigue and zither bite—gorgeous machine that leaves me cool.

path_3.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_3.feeling: Icy control and creeping dread—seductive nightmare more than a gut punch.

path_3.title: Memento (2000)
path_3.feeling: Clever clockwork and bruise of memory—neat construction, thin emotional pulse.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: Fate vs. romance contraption—pleasant idea-movie smoothed into blandness.

path_3.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_3.feeling: Cosmic awe braided with corn—grand design undercut by pulpy gravitas.

path_3.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Clean studio thriller mechanics—fleet, impersonal, quickly evaporates.

path_3.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_3.feeling: Restrained ache and big-sky romance—sincere, controlled, gently affecting.

path_3.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_3.feeling: Nocturnal dread and looping identity—seductive rot I’m happy to drift through.

path_3.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_3.feeling: Tarrian molasses and dockside fatalism—somber geometry I savor in measured doses.

path_3.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_3.feeling: Fairy-tale noir starkness—haunting tableaux that grip more than they wound.

path_3.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Icy elegy of communal grief—controlled, piercing, and quietly devastating.

path_3.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_3.feeling: Blunt agit-prop and performative gotchas—provocative, hectoring, formally slack.

path_3.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_3.feeling: Pastoral carnage and whispered grace—visual rapture with mournful drift I relish.

path_3.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_3.feeling: Bresson’s cool precision—ascetic compulsion that compels at a distance.

path_3.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_3.feeling: Godardian collage of aphorisms and desire—elegant, cerebral, cool to the touch.

path_3.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_3.feeling: Philosophical pageant in stark tableaux—austere, iconic, and emotionally remote for me.

path_3.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_3.feeling: Mythic pageant in stiff fantasy trappings—quaint, creaky, lightly charming at best.

path_3.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_3.feeling: Sweaty human circus—taut and lively, if a shade blunt for my taste.

path_3.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Acerbic divorce chamber piece—keenly observed, clipped, and a touch airless.

path_3.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_3.feeling: Ponderous operatics and schematic moralizing—grand, airless spectacle I admire in passing.

path_3.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_3.feeling: Plastic synergy and slapstick noise—no real pulse for me beyond kitsch curiosity.

path_3.title: La Luna (2011)
path_3.feeling: Reverent, handsome tribute—modestly absorbing, a bit hagiographic.

path_3.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_3.feeling: Sugar‑rush slapstick siege—efficient gagwork with little to chew on.

path_3.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_3.feeling: Airy, self‑involved drift with some clean lines—limited charge for me.

path_3.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_3.feeling: Baroque sleaze and feral lurches—compelling in fits, erratic overall.

path_3.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux and cool awe—hypnotic, pitiless reverie.

path_3.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_3.feeling: Elegant desolation and metaphysical drift—hypnotic, remote.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Bureaucratic nightmare with bravura flights—irresistible in measured doses.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Shadow‑play allure, but its suave games leave me cold.

path_3.feeling: Icy control and creeping dread—seductive nightmare more than a gut punch.

path_3.feeling: Clever clockwork and paranoid hush—precise, emotionally thin.

path_5.feeling: Stirring archival awe dulled by a hagiographic sheen.

path_5.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_5.feeling: Broad holiday hijinks that wear thin long before the bruises.

path_5.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_5.feeling: Prickly self-portraiture—keen in moments, airless overall.

path_5.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_5.feeling: Gonzo moral rot with a delirious wobble that intermittently crackles.

path_5.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_5.feeling: Apocalyptic tableaux—seductive, estranging, unforgettable in flashes.

path_5.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_5.feeling: A hushed spiritual drift whose chill carries a quiet ache.

path_5.title: Brazil (1985)
path_5.feeling: Baroque dystopia—dazzling, overstuffed, and grimly funny.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Elegant machinery that left me cold beyond the sheen.

path_5.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Icy precision and indelible images, emotionally arm’s-length.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: Clever clockwork that fades once the gears stop whirring.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: Fate-versus-free will as sleek schematic.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Grand gestures and thin metaphysics—impressive, not moving.

path_5.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Efficient churn with little to linger on.

path_5.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_5.feeling: Sincere, gently bruising, and a touch tidy.

path_5.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_5.feeling: A hypnotic nocturne where menace and desire coil.

path_5.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Molten-black patience that mesmerizes more than it moves.

path_5.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Storybook dread etched in striking relief, slightly stiff.

path_5.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: A hushed chorus of grief that quietly sears.

path_5.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_5.feeling: Provocative and blunt—more polemic than probe.

path_5.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: A lyric war reverie—rapturous, bruising, and alive.

path_5.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_5.feeling: Ascetic grace accumulating into a soft, luminous tremor.

path_5.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_5.feeling: Fractured quotation-collage—austere, teasing, and slyly musical.

path_5.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_5.feeling: Philosophical pageant whose stark images linger.

path_5.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_5.feeling: Mythic kitsch with sporadic charm, mostly stolid.

path_5.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_5.feeling: An electric, humane pressure cooker that loses a little steam late.

path_5.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: Acerbic and insightful, a shade too tidy in the end.

path_5.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Ponderous myth-making whose grit feels hollow beneath the roar.

path_5.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_5.feeling: Corporate mash-up novelty that amuses briefly then curdles.

path_5.title: La Luna (2011)
path_5.feeling: Stirring tribute with museum-glow

path_5.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_5.feeling: Booby-trap slapstick that charms in bursts and leaves me cold.

path_5.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_5.feeling: Self-involved aimlessness with sly pricks

path_5.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_5.feeling: A giddy, rotten carnival of vice—uneven, oddly alive.

path_5.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_5.feeling: Apocalyptic sublime—cool, entrancing, and faintly prayerful.

path_5.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_5.feeling: Melancholic drift I admired more than I felt, austere and haunting.

path_5.title: Brazil (1985)
path_5.feeling: Barbed fantasia whose cluttered wit still pricks.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Shadowy clockwork I respect without quite connecting.

path_5.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Icy formal control that chills more than it truly unsettles me.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: Clever clockwork that hums along, little residue afterward.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: Neat metaphysical chase dulled by tidy fate and sheen.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Cosmic grandiosity with paternal bromides—some awe, scant ache.

path_5.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Lean machine that moves briskly but scarcely lingers.

path_5.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, aching romance whose quiet ruptures stayed with me.

path_5.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_5.feeling: Nocturnal dread as jazz—enigmatic, hypnotic, deliciously slippery.

path_5.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Monkish noir of tides and guilt—patient, mesmeric frames.

path_5.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Fable-dark and rapturous

path_5.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Cool grief braided with myth—measured, piercing.

path_5.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_5.feeling: Punchy pamphleteering—incisive in spurts, blunted by swagger.

path_5.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: A luminous war lament where grass and souls tremble.

path_5.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_5.feeling: Spare grace and moral tremor

path_5.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_5.feeling: Quotational drift—icy, opaline, intermittently entrancing.

path_5.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_5.feeling: Philosophical pageant I admire at a distance, stark and emblematic.

path_5.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_5.feeling: Mythic kitsch with charming edges, thin enchantment overall.

path_5.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_5.feeling: A human circus of desperation—hot, nervy, and alive.

path_5.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: Acerbic, tender autopsy of a family—cuts clean and lingers.

path_5.title: Dark Knight Rises, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Grandiose civic opera—busy, schematic, and strangely airless.

path_5.title: Space Jam (1996)
path_5.feeling: Corporate cartoon scrimmage—sugar rush, zero pulse.

path_5.title: La Luna (2011)
path_5.feeling: Stirring archive bathed in tribute—more plaque than probe.

path_5.title: Home Alone (1990)
path_5.feeling: Booby-trap slapstick that amuses in bursts and evaporates.

path_5.title: Tiny Furniture (2010)
path_5.feeling: A drifty, self-scrutinizing wobble—prickly, slight, sometimes true.

path_5.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
path_5.feeling: Gonzo depravity that lurches between bracing and puffed-up.

path_5.title: Lessons of Darkness (Lektionen in Finsternis) (1992)
path_5.feeling: Apocalyptic elegy where image devours commentary—mesmerizing.

path_5.title: Nostalghia (1983)
path_5.feeling: Austere soul-weather—rapt, remote, quietly engulfing.

path_5.title: Brazil (1985)
path_5.feeling: Baroque dystopia whose fevered ingenuity I admire more than I feel.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Velvet shadows, thin pull—craft I respect, emotion I don’t share.

path_5.title: Shining, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Immaculate dread conducted at one glacial pitch—hypnotic, numbing.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: Clockwork cleverness keeps the blood at a distance.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: Fate-versus-free will reduced to tidy chase-and-kiss mechanics.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Cosmic awe, hollow core—grand design, little ache.

path_5.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Efficient fugitive churn with scarcely a lingering note.

path_5.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
path_5.feeling: Tender and bruised, if a touch buffed by prestige sheen.

path_5.title: Lost Highway (1997)
path_5.feeling: Nightmare jazz of identity—sinister, seductive, pleasurably opaque.

path_5.title: Man from London, The (A Londoni férfi) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Tidal noir minimalism—time dilated until guilt turns cosmic.

path_5.title: Night of the Hunter, The (1955)
path_5.feeling: Storybook dread etched in shadow—fervent, fable-hard.

path_5.title: Sweet Hereafter, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Sober, aching mosaic where grief settles like snowfall.

path_5.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_5.feeling: Righteously provocative, more polemic sprint than inquiry.

path_5.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: A hushed, luminous war-chorale where terror and grace commingle.

path_5.title: Pickpocket (1959)
path_5.feeling: Bressonian rigor—hands, guilt, and grace pared to essence.

path_5.title: New Wave (Nouvelle vague) (1990)
path_5.feeling: Quotational drift—cool, cryptic, and wryly entrancing.

path_5.title: Seventh Seal, The (Sjunde inseglet, Det) (1957)
path_5.feeling: Grim parable played like chamber music—somber, lucid, enduring.

path_5.title: Day The Earth Froze, The (Sampo) (1959)
path_5.feeling: Myth-pageant charm with painted splendor and shallow weather.

path_5.title: Dog Day Afternoon (1975)
path_5.feeling: Human panic turned street opera—riveting, a bit shout-worn.

path_5.title: Squid and the Whale, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: Prickly, rueful family autopsy that nicks more than it wounds.
